author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Matthew Barney, Back in the Game
description: In his new video installation, the artist known for maximalist works like “The Cremaster Cycle” returns to the football fields of his childhood.
content: The hit, 45 years ago, shook up the world of football. Then, just as quickly, people moved on. But not Darryl Stingley, the receiver for the New England Patriots who bore the head-on charge by Jack Tatum of the Oakland Raiders. Stingley was rendered quadriplegic. Tatum, a defender known as “The Assassin,” notoriously never apologized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Jayson Tatum Scores 51 as Celtics Rout Sixers in Game 7
description: Tatum’s scoring output was an N.B.A. record for a Game 7, and it helped send the Celtics to the Eastern Conference finals, where they will face the Miami Heat.
content: BOSTON — Jaylen Brown had used his public platform ahead of Sunday afternoon’s game to deliver a clear message to Celtics fans: Get loud. The energy at TD Garden for the team’s home games during its N.B.A. Eastern Conference semifinal series with the Philadelphia 76ers had been merely OK, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Thailand’s Election: What to Watch and What’s at Stake
description: The vote is seen as a referendum on the military, which has ruled Thailand for nine years. Results could determine the path for democracy in the country.
content: Thai voters headed to the polls on Sunday in a hotly contested election that will determine whether Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, the general who seized power in a coup in 2014, is unseated by his rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: What’s the Point of Your 20s? Ask the Patron Saint of Striving Youth.
description: Meg Jay knows it’s confusing to figure out what to do with your life. She also knows you need to get on with it.
content: Imagine you’ve been plunked into the ocean. You can’t spot land. You’re treading water, your arms are spaghetti-limp and all you see is blue. You get the sense that this could be it forever: you against the currents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: Platform Agnostic for Nearly 100 Years
description: In 1928, The New York Times wrapped an electric bulletin board around its headquarters to deliver breaking news to the throng of Times Square.
content: Why wait for the morning edition when you can write the news in light?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: He Told Followers to Starve to Meet Jesus. Why Did So Many Do It?
description: Hundreds were drawn to a remote wilderness in southeastern Kenya by the End Times preaching of pastor Paul Mackenzie. Relatives and ex-members tried to intervene, but some did not want to be rescued.
content: Delirious from hunger, a believer who had brought his family to live with a Christian doomsday cult in a remote wilderness in southeastern Kenya sent a distraught text to his younger sister last week. While he begged for her help to escape, he was still in the grip of the preacher who had lured him there, promising salvation through death by starvation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qian Julie Wang
title: Two Memoirs of Chinese American Hunger, Three Decades Apart
description: Fae Myenne Ng’s “Orphan Bachelors” recalls her coming of age in midcentury San Francisco; Jane Wong’s “Meet Me Tonight in Atlantic City” recalls hers in 1980s and ’90s New Jersey.
content: My earliest memory of community is of walking around my birth city in northern China with my mother and grandparents, receiving greetings of “Have you eaten?” from friends and acquaintances and assuring everyone, “We have.” Decades later, when my grandfather unexpectedly died during the Covid pandemic before China reopened its borders, my mother took shelter in her kitchen in New Jersey, cooking nightly until dawn. A stream of stir-fries, soups and sweets appeared at my door just a few miles away; on my phone, a text: “Have you eaten?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Managing Screen Time Is a Family Matter
description: Parents must help their children live healthier digital lives.
content: For the next three weeks, I’ll be exploring digital asceticism, the role of technology in our lives and how to maintain our humanity in an increasingly technological world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria M. Walker
title: An American Express Airport Lounge in the Sky? Not Quite.
description: American Express has opened its first Centurion members club, an 11,500-square-foot space with wraparound views of Manhattan.
content: Another members-only club has opened in New York. But unlike its predecessors, which include Soho House, Aman, Casa Cipriani, and others, the Centurion New York was designed not by an architect or hotelier — but by a credit card company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 15, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Brief Rocket Fire Disrupts Gaza Cease-Fire. How Long Can the Truce Last?
description: Another violent escalation in Gaza ended in another cease-fire. But it did not completely halt the rocket fire and the region’s instability means the next conflagration is never far away.
content: A cease-fire between Israel and Palestinian fighters in the Gaza Strip was largely upheld on Sunday, aside from a brief exchange of fire in the evening, and routine returned hours after the two sides agreed to end a five-day escalation that killed at least 33 people in Gaza and two in Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As I Entered the Gallery, I Saw a Well-Dressed, Middle-Aged Woman’
description: A surprise at the Met, a hot summer night in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Speeding Up the Update of Our Electrical Grid
description: Readers discuss an editorial that urged a new process for getting power lines approved. Also: Stories about puberty, for kids; artificial intelligence.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: ‘The Diplomat’ vs. Reality
description: A popular show on Netflix is about the glamorous job of a U.S. ambassador. But is it realistic?
content: The allure of an ambassador’s life is obvious: wielding government power and throwing parties for influential people in a far-flung location. “The Diplomat,” which premiered last month on Netflix, highlights the glamour while omitting the drudgery of the job — the memos, press engagements and red tape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: When the Rule of Law Fails Us
description: This was a preventable tragedy.
content: Civil society cannot exist when the rule of law fails, and that includes on the nation’s streets and public transit systems. The rule of law has to apply to the most and least powerful citizens, or we will create a culture of impunity that can disrupt daily lives and, ultimately, dangerously destabilize communities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 14, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 14, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about Turkey’s presidential election gave an incorrect title for Victor Orban of Hungary. He is the prime minister, not the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael W. McConnell
title: The Case for Violating the Debt Limit Is Dangerous Nonsense
description: The president does not have the authority to exceed the limit, regardless of what his advisers are telling him.
content: President Biden is playing a dangerous game. When the federal government’s deficit spending is about to exceed the amount Congress has authorized it to borrow and the Treasury has run out of what are known as extraordinary measures to stave off disaster, Congress and the president must negotiate a compromise resolution, or the nation faces the prospect of default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: You Can Ignore the Bridezilla in the Breakroom
description: A colleague’s wedding — even if she won’t stop talking about it — doesn’t mean you need to spend money you don’t want to spend.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: A Lifetime of Stories, and Still More to Tell
description: Nearly 80 years ago, Milton Esterow began a career at The New York Times that would forever change art and culture reporting. At 94, he’s still churning out articles.
content: In 1938, an article in The Monthly Star Eagle reported that a truck had crashed into a car on New Lots Avenue in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: It’s Been a Week. What Does It Tell Us About 2024?
description: The presidential race has started to crystallize, with flawed standard-bearers, worried political parties and voters unhappy with their choices.
content: Eighteen months is an eternity in politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gulsin Harman
title: Who will win the elections? Turkey’s astrologers find answers in the stars.
description: Amid economic uncertainty and the most competitive elections in years, interest in fortune tellers has surged in Turkey.
content: In the weeks leading up to Turkey’s tightest elections in two decades, some of the 64 million eligible voters didn’t look to opinion polls for predictions about the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Meet ‘Chonkosaurus,’ the Thick Snapping Turtle Stealing Hearts
description: The gargantuan animal has enthralled thousands online after a kayaker on the Chicago River recorded it sitting on a rusted chain.
content: Even from afar, the snapping turtle perched on rusted chains in the Chicago River looked gargantuan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
title: Rules for Pentagon Use of Proxy Forces Shed Light on a Shadowy War Power
description: Newly disclosed documents include Special Operations forces directives for managing counterterrorism and irregular warfare surrogate fighters.
content: U.S. Special Operations forces are not required to vet for past human rights violations by the foreign troops they arm and train as surrogates, newly disclosed documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis Impresses in Iowa, Showing Up an Absent Trump
description: The former president canceled a rally in Des Moines, citing a storm warning. The Florida governor made the most of his rival’s absence, as DeSantis allies taunted Mr. Trump.
content: For the first time in months, Gov. Ron DeSantis on Saturday showed the aggressive political instincts that his allies have long insisted he would demonstrate in a contest against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: When Your Champions League Dream Runs Through a War Zone
description: Shakhtar Donetsk’s foreign stars fled Ukraine when Russia invaded. Now some are returning or signing up, proof that the lure of opportunity can trump fear.
content: By the time Lassina Traoré returned to his team, everybody else was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A Grandson Investigates the ‘Reasonable’ Nazi in the Family
description: In “Fatherland,” Burkhard Bilger sifts through his German grandfather’s confounding identities — teacher, soldier, party chief, traitor.
content: Every family tree has a twisted branch or two. Burkhard Bilger’s is unusually gnarly. His maternal grandfather, Karl Gönner, was a Nazi Party chief in the village of Bartenheim, in the long-contested Alsace region. Instead of cutting down and burying this rotten bough, Bilger decided to climb to it, build a sturdy perch, have a long look around and report his findings in a new memoir, “Fatherland.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ravi Mattu
title: Who Would Want to Be a C.E.O.?
description: The challenges facing business leaders feel particularly acute right now. This week, DealBook delved into four of them.
content: Who would want to be a chief executive?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arin Yoon
title: How a Military Base’s New Name Honors a Military Spouse and Mother
description: Fort Benning is now officially Fort Moore, the only U.S. base named for a married couple.
content: Lt. Gen. Harold G. Moore commanded troops in the first major battle of the Vietnam War, a role depicted in a book and a movie. His wife, Julia, was a champion for military spouses and changed the way next of kin are notified when a service member is killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Bill Oesterle, Co-Founder of Angie’s List, Dies at 57
description: What began as a company to review local contractors grew into a website with millions of subscribers. He was also involved in Republican Party politics in Indiana.
content: Bill Oesterle, a founder and the longtime chief executive of the service review website Angie’s List, who also ran Mitch Daniels’s first campaign for governor of Indiana but later clashed with the state’s Republican establishment, died on Wednesday at his home in Indianapolis. He was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Frame of Mind
description: Tomas Spiers starts our week with a little fun.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Tori Bowie’s Hometown Celebrates Her Life Amid Mystery of Her Death
description: Mourners at a visitation and funeral in Mississippi remembered Tori Bowie as an inspiration on the track while also searching for answers about how her life ended.
content: BRANDON, Miss. — Before she became a three-time Olympic medalist and before she earned the title of world’s fastest woman, Frentorish Bowie welcomed a camera crew to her hometown, Sandhill, Miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Spring Dressing Isn’t Impossible
description: The key? Don’t worry about following rules.
content: Thanks to a popular saying, most people in New York expect April showers. Almost just as predictable: the confusion over how to dress in the transitional weeks of spring, when the temperature can go from cold to warm to hot, sometimes in a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland and Lexi Parra
title: Politics, Police, Pozole: The Battle for Sunset Park
description: An impromptu street market in a Brooklyn park was a lifeline for immigrants during the pandemic. But then came complaints and conflicts, and then the police.
content: For Sonia Cortes, the battle for Sunset Park began with soup. Two years ago, after the pandemic wiped out her job as a seamstress, Ms. Cortes started selling pozole, a brothy Mexican soup, in the park, a 25-acre swath of green in southwestern Brooklyn. On a good Sunday, she could make $600 or $700. “I was able to pay my rent,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Struggle to Save Abdul
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 14, 2023.
content: “If there’s any way I can be saved, please save me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Don Denkinger, Umpire Remembered for Botched Call, Dies at 86
description: His reputation as a longtime major-league umpire was overshadowed by a wrong call he made during the 1985 World Series.
content: Don Denkinger was regarded as one of the finest major-league umpires of his time. Working in the American League from 1969 to 1998, he was assigned to four World Series and three All-Star Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Silky Scrambled Eggs With a Carbonara Complex
description: Pecorino and pancetta elevate eggs, black pepper punches up chicken, and lemon and capers make mushrooms into a piccata.
content: Good morning. Happy Mother’s Day to all who celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Trump on TV
description: Inflation continues to slow. Elon Musk says he’s found a new C.E.O. for Twitter. And there will be a pair of Senate hearings on the banking crisis.
content: Until last week, former President Donald J. Trump had not appeared on CNN since 2016. But at a town hall hosted by the network on Wednesday night, Mr. Trump, the Republican front-runner in the 2024 presidential campaign, resumed the lies and name-calling that marked his presidency. Answering questions from the anchor Kaitlan Collins, he repeated misinformation about the 2020 election, called the writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a suit accusing him of sexual abuse and defamation, a “wack job” and derided Ms. Collins as a “nasty person.” When Ms. Collins tried to correct Mr. Trump’s lies, he often talked over her. The largely sympathetic audience cheered him on throughout the evening. Critics of CNN’s forum said it was reckless to give Mr. Trump such a large platform for his message, especially because it proved difficult to fact check his statements in real time. The chairman of CNN, Chris Licht, defended the broadcast on Thursday, saying it underscored that covering Mr. Trump would “continue to be messy and tricky.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith and Karl Russell
title: The Greatest Wealth Transfer in History Is Here, With Familiar (Rich) Winners
description: In an era of surging home and stock values, U.S. family wealth has soared. The trillions of dollars going to heirs will largely reinforce inequality.
content: An intergenerational transfer of wealth is in motion in America — and it will dwarf any of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Leaders Stay, Others Run
description: Real heroes stay behind.
content: When war broke out unexpectedly in the streets of Khartoum, Dr. Hiba Omer, a senior surgeon, could have fled like so many others. Instead, she stayed behind to keep a hospital open. Her city was in its hour of greatest need. If she left, who would perform the C-sections and treat all those bullet wounds? Even after a Sudanese military official accused her on social media of siding with its enemy, the R.S.F. militia, sparking a barrage of death threats against her, she refused to flee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: A New Mother, an Old Mother, a Love Story
description: We travel with our ghosts. Who better to lead us to what comes next?
content: I was 8 when my mother died. She died at 35 of breast cancer, though it would be years before I knew that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Over Decades, Congress Failed Repeatedly to Address Immigration Dysfunction
description: Legislative initiatives to overhaul immigration policy have fallen flat as partisan differences and other rifts have scuttled attempts at compromise.
content: For nearly a quarter century, as successive waves of migrants have tried to enter and work in the United States, presidents have appealed to Congress to address gaps in an immigration system nearly everyone agrees is broken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Ja Morant Suspended Again for Possible New Gun Video
description: Morant, the star Memphis Grizzlies guard, was first suspended in March after he flashed a gun during an Instagram Live video.
content: Memphis Grizzlies guard Ja Morant, 23, is under scrutiny from the N.B.A. again after he flashed an object that looked like a gun in a carefree manner during an Instagram Live video posted over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: 5 Moments That Defined Trump’s Record on Immigration
description: Donald. J. Trump made the border a central focus of his 2016 campaign. As president, he relied on cruelty and fear to deter migrants from the United States.
content: When Donald J. Trump became president, he immediately set out to change the country’s immigration system, including with a travel ban that mostly affected countries with large Muslim populations and by making stark changes at the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Thailand Votes for Change
description: Thai voters overwhelmingly sought to end nearly a decade of military rule, casting ballots in favor of two opposition parties that have pledged to curtail the power of two powerful conservative institutions: the military and the monarchy.
content: Thai voters overwhelmingly sought to end nearly a decade of military rule, casting ballots in favor of two opposition parties that have pledged to curtail the power of two powerful conservative institutions: the military and the monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeneen Interlandi, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Lifesaving Power of … Paperwork?’
description: One of the most powerful public health measures is simply recording every birth and death. In rural Colombia, as in much of the world, it’s a lot harder than it sounds.
content: In the final days of Marleny Mesa’s pregnancy, she could not shake the feeling that something was wrong. She could barely breathe, for one thing. For another, her anxiety and physical discomfort were approaching what felt like an unbearable peak. A week or so later, she delivered a tiny, squirming boy with jet black hair and soft, curious eyes. She and her husband, Andrés Noscue, named him Eliad. Marleny thought he was perfect, but her mother, a retired midwife, insisted that the placenta contained a hint of trouble. It was far too big, she said, and Eliad was too small, probably because he did not have enough room in her womb to grow. His grandmother thought he might need an incubator. Marleny thought he was fine, but when the baby was a few days old, she and Andrés traveled from the Jerusalén-San Luis Alto Picudito Indigenous reservation in Putumayo, Colombia, to take him to Villagarzón for a checkup, just to be safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: In Blow to Junta, Thai Voters Overwhelmingly Back Opposition Parties
description: Thais on Sunday cast votes against their military leaders, backing instead a populist political mainstay and a progressive upstart bent on shaking up the status quo.
content: Voters in Thailand overwhelmingly sought to end nearly a decade of military rule on Sunday, casting ballots in favor of two opposition parties that have pledged to curtail the power of the country’s powerful conservative institutions: the military and the monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Zelensky Visits Germany, Praising Weapons Pledge and Seeking Jets
description: The Ukrainian president was received with military honors in Berlin, where he thanked Germany’s leaders for standing with his country.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met with Germany’s leaders in Berlin on Sunday, his latest stop on a diplomatic tour aimed at shoring up support among Western allies and pushing for faster deliveries of weapons as a Ukrainian counteroffensive looms in the 15-month war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Making a Michael J. Fox Movie With Michael J. Fox’s Movies
description: How the documentary “Still” uses footage from its subject’s films and TV shows to tell its story.
content: When Davis Guggenheim approached Michael J. Fox three years ago in the hopes of making a film about his life, the director had a few things going for him, besides his previous success with documentaries about other luminaries including Al Gore (the Oscar-winning “An Inconvenient Truth”) and the Pakistani activist Malala Yousafzai (“He Named Me Malala”). Guggenheim’s wife, the actress Elisabeth Shue, had worked with Fox before, starring as his girlfriend in the second and third installments of the “Back to the Future” series. And Guggenheim had directed “It Might Get Loud,” a documentary about Jimmy Page, Jack White and The Edge, a fact that endeared him to Fox, a longtime electric guitar player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Philadelphia Democrats Clash: 5 Things to Know About the Mayor’s Race
description: The winner of the Democratic contest is all but certain to become the next mayor of Philadelphia and could play a key role in the 2024 presidential election.
content: Amid grave concerns about public safety, education and the direction of a major American city, Philadelphians will take a major step on Tuesday toward electing their 100th mayor in a contest with implications that will reverberate across a crucial presidential battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: On the Right, Support and Donations Pour In for Daniel Penny
description: Mr. Penny, who has been charged with killing Jordan Neely, has been called a “hero” and a good Samaritan by conservative political figures.
content: Little is known about the political views of Daniel Penny, the ex-Marine charged with fatally choking Jordan Neely on a New York City subway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Owen Davidson, Who Won 8 Grand Slams With Billie Jean King, Dies at 79
description: In the 1960s and ’70s, he and King dominated mixed doubles tournaments. He was also known for his congeniality, sportsmanship and skill at the net.
content: Owen Davidson, an Australian tennis player who formed a dominant mixed doubles team with Billie Jean King in the 1960s and ’70s, winning eight Grand Slam titles with her, along with five doubles titles with other partners, died on Friday in Conroe, Texas, a suburb of Houston. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nikki Haley Says Pledging a Federal Abortion Ban Wouldn’t Be ‘Honest’
description: “I think the media has tried to divide them by saying we have to decide certain weeks,” Ms. Haley said in an interview on CBS News. “In states, yes. At the federal level, it’s not realistic.”
content: The Republican presidential candidate Nikki Haley refused on Sunday to endorse a federal abortion ban at a specific number of weeks’ gestation, saying that to do so would be to lie to the American people about what is politically possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How the Head of a Filmmaking Center Spends His Sundays
description: Jon Alpert has shared his love for documentaries with New Yorkers for more than 50 years.
content: In the late 1960s, Jon Alpert conspired with his neighbor, Keiko Tsuno, to start making short films that tackled certain conditions and issues in Chinatown that they wanted to change. Making the documentaries “was like waving a magic wand,” he said. “We began winning the fights and realized the power we had.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
title: Nail-Biter Turkish Election Goes to Round 2 as Majority Eludes Erdogan
description: After two decades in power, a struggling Recep Tayyip Erdogan now has two more weeks to persuade Turkish voters that he is the best choice to lead the country.
content: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkey’s presidential election appeared on Sunday to be headed for a runoff after the incumbent, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, failed to win a majority of the vote, a result that left the longtime leader struggling to stave off the toughest political challenge of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams Says He’s a Progressive. Democrats Beg to Differ.
description: Left-leaning New Yorkers say the mayor is moving the city in a more conservative direction on issues like policing, rent and providing shelter to those in need.
content: When a homeless man was choked to death on the New York City subway earlier this month by another passenger, Mayor Eric Adams had an uncharacteristically guarded response. For more than a week, he did not denounce the killing, as many of his Democratic colleagues immediately had, or express much sympathy for the victim, Jordan Neely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
title: As Ukraine Makes Inroads in Bakhmut, Devastation Still Reigns
description: The fight for Bakhmut is now the war’s single longest and bloodiest battle. Although the Ukrainians are making small gains, Russia still controls about 90 percent of the largely ruined city.
content: With the furious battle for the city of Bakhmut raging at their backs, a squad of Ukrainian soldiers tore through an open field, racing to get out of range of falling Russian artillery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Tiff Fehr and Charlie Smart
title: How to Raise $89 Million in Small Donations, and Make It Disappear
description: A group of conservative operatives using sophisticated robocalls raised millions of dollars from donors using pro-police and pro-veteran messages. But instead of using the money to promote issues and candidates, an analysis by The New York Times shows, nearly all the money went to pay the firms making the calls and the operatives themselves.
content: A group of conservative operatives using sophisticated robocalls raised millions of dollars from donors using pro-police and pro-veteran messages. But instead of using the money to promote issues and candidates, an analysis by The New York Times shows, nearly all the money went to pay the firms making the calls and the operatives themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Joy, Loneliness, ‘Rejuvenation:’ Becoming a Mother After 40
description: More American women are having kids later in life. Here’s what some have to say about it.
content: More American women are having kids later in life. Here’s what some have to say about it.
source.name: The New York Times
